Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 04:15PM DianeE wrote: Amber, I have been waiting for your results and I am so so sad to see what you now have to decide.  It is such a big one.  No one knows the future, but like you said, the taxol was working.  The feeling of not being in control of your body, schedule, and some household things seems so overwhelming, but I would not want it to get out of control or worry constantly that I had waited too long.  You are the only one that can make this decision.  I can tell from your posts that you are a wonderful mom and your kids will still have a wonderful Mom should you decide to restart the chemo right away.  Maybe it would give them a little extra time to get used to the chage in the house before school started.  I will be praying for you Amber.  Diane

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2008 04:20PM - edited Mar 1, 2008 06:57PM by DianeE Deb, I have followed your posts for awhile since I came on board and have always found you so uplifting, true and honest with your posts.  You have been told what so many of us fear and so many others are living.  My heart aches for you and your family.  Please know we are all thinking of you and will be here praying for you.  I work in an oncology lab and we have many, many patients who are stage IV and are having a good QOL, have control over their disease with newer treatments and I know that will happen for you.  So Deb, hugs from Wisconsin and across the world are coming your way.  You are amazing!! Diane

Posts.Title: Fare Thee Well Love.... joannes_brother lewisfamily503

Posts.Content: DianeE wrote: I had doulbe mx 12/07 with ADN on left and simple on right.  Right rads to follow including superclav area.  In 4/08 I did 3 months of lymphedema clinic that seemed to help.  I then went on my merry way and would monitor my arm and some truncal lymphedema and throw in a self lymph massage from time to time.  I do notice a fuller feeling under both arms now and swelling on the rib cage on both the left and right.  I have a PET/CT scheduled for Dec 11 with an appointment and I really do not want to go in ahead of this.  Do any of you think this could be lymphedema or do you have experience that says is might be something more serious.  I am in overdrive preparing for Christmas and potential bad news on the 11th and I can not shake the here we go again feeling.  Any thoughts would be greatly appreciated.  I am trying to stay positive for the kids and do extra things with them right now, but I am really anxious and scared. Thank you Diane Dx 7/7/2007, IBC, 2cm, Stage IIIB, Grade 3, 2/22 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2008 05:09PM DianeE wrote: Julie, So sorry that you have to worry about this!!!  I have IBC and also had an MRI, but it was a false positive on one side.  So, try and take this all one baby step at a time and do not give into the worst case scenario yet.  It is great that your MD is being proactive, but the MRI is not the final answer.  I will be thinking benign thoughts for you and praying this is just post baby breast pain. Diane
Posts.Title: mri and ibc julieup DianeE

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2008 02:25PM DianeE wrote: Tender, It was so good to see that you were still reading and I hope you have read the postings in response to your "Tenderly leaving this Might group" posting.  That being said, everyone of us understands each person has to decide for themselves what to do and I hope our desperate pleas for your return are not the reason that brought you back.  You are a dynamic person with a lot to offer and give.  I so respect your posts and your decision to step away for awhile if that is what you need to do.  If what you want is to come back then......YIPPEEE!!  Welcome back, I really missed you.  It is such a strange feeling to miss someone you do not know except through our shared diagnosis and communication.  So, Tender, what ever you decide, know that you are loved and respected here. Diane
Posts.Title: Where is Tender ? riverinerabbit Gitane

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 10:27PM DianeE wrote: I am going through this exact thing right now.  I had TAC last fall with my last treatment being 11/07.  I had hormone levels drawn in 2/08 that indicated I was "almost" menopausal.  No period since 8/07.  (I'm 41 by the way).  I have been on tamoxifen since April.  I have told my onc all along that I could still sense my daughters cycle, I felt crampy at the time of her periods and we used to cycle together.  One month ago I had a normal pelvic and pap exam.  So now, since Monday I have had a very heavy period.  I talked to my onc and his first response was that I needed a vag ultrasound.  When I told him I had an exam a month ago, he was very comfortable just drawing the hormones to check things out.  My LH dropped from 49 to 3.1 and the FSH and Estradiol are still pending.  It looks like I am out of chemopause.  Crap.  I will have to wait and see what my onc says once all labs are back.  He did say he had a hard time believing after 13+ months that I would come back out and  added "hmm., glad you're on tamoxifen" .  On a side note, I work in the lab at my cancer center so I see my onc daily and have really had personalized care and I know he has really gone to great lengths for me between tumor boards and phone consults with 3 other cancer centers, so I do trust him.  Any thoughts anyone? Diane
Posts.Title: periods Tracy1964 Stack

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2008 03:40AM DianeE wrote: Are you taking any other meds right now?   Tamoxifen has a rare side effect of decreaed wbc, but it is rare.  Have you been feeling o.k.?  Any viral like symptoms?  Maybe you just have a bug and happened to have your labs checked during it.  If your onc is worried at all, they could bring you back in for a repeat CBC in a few weeks and see if has resolved on its own.  Diane
Posts.Title: wbc drop several months after chemo lopsided_blogger DianeE

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2008 01:05PM DianeE wrote: Janis, Good luck with your recovery.  Maybe Santa will visit your room while you are in the hospital.  Rest up and let your cute little guys pamper you.  Diane
Posts.Title: I will be offline for a few days.. Fitztwins LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 10:21PM DianeE wrote: Annie, Congratulations and thank you for sharing.  Here is to 50 more NED years for you and for all. Diane
Posts.Title: Still NED Annie62 S3K5

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 10:40PM DianeE wrote: Hey Feb rad girls Ddouma, I too had to pose for pictures while on the table.  They do this so in addition to the measrements and degrees they have in the computer for you, it helps to know how you are positioned for the simulation and future treatments.  I know how you feel about the marks on your chest.  My techs use paint pens and each day someone is sneaking it out of their pocket and adding a few marks.  I really do not mind as they have to be so exact and the techs I have are wonderful.  I have started my boosts and have only 2 left of 33 to go.  I saw the Rad Onc today and he said his female patients are a wonder to him as they just keep plugging along and try and keep on with life as much as possible.  I love that man.  At the end of the appointment he took my hands in his and said "God Bless you sweetheart.  I am sorry I had to do this to you but remember I want you to live to be an old lady and I am so glad you are nearly done."  I am so thankful for compassionate physicians that really get it.  So Feb gals, keep plugging along.  The treatment numbers will dwindle, the skin will be sensitive, itchy and sometimes sore, but you can do this.  You're all stronger than you know, and we are all in it together.  Think of me Friday as I jump off that table for the last time and skip out of the treatment room, soon enough you will be doing the same.  Stay strong, have faith and breathe. Diane
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 09:45PM DianeE wrote: Ulla, I have inflammatory breast cancer which is always a stage III.  My stage IIIb has actually been moved to a stage IIIc as after tumor board met regarding my case, they found an enlarged internal mammary node so with the axillary nodes, it becomes IIIc.  I also had invasive ductal and dcis on biopsy, but it all presented with IBC symptoms, so stage III. I really think it is all a crap shoot anyways and I try not to focus on the stats and stages. Take care Diane
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2008 11:07AM - edited Jan 30, 2008 11:11AM by DianeE Hi June, I also usually worked 32 hours a week, but during rads have reduced to 18-24 hours each week.  I had a double mas 12/3 after 5 months of chemo and did not work during that time so part of it is easing back into my schedule.  I have had 15 treatments so far and have just started to feel the fatigue.  One reason I am working a reduced amount is that my kids are 12 and 9 and busy with sports and school and I did not want to miss out on any of it.  So, my work has been very flexible and understanding and I plan to return back to my normal schedule as soon as I am ready.  It helps that I actually work at an oncology office too.  Remember to take time for yourself and give your body time to rest and heal.  Good luck to you and everyone else in the Feb club and lube up with whatever lotion they give you.  You do not want your skin to break down. Diane
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2008 06:09PM DianeE wrote: June, Sorry your simulation and first treatment were so difficult.  At my simulation, I could not hold my arm above my head so they spent about a half hour trying different positions for me to be in and the said they would do electron therapy istead of photon to the chest wall.  I think they are able to do this becase of the double mass and the electron radiation only penetrates centimeters where as the photon radiation goes all the way.  They do use the photon for above the collar bone.  The other person you asked about helps to determine the angle and dosing of the radiaition along with your radiation oncologist.  I am suprised that they said you would not need anything till the end of week three.  It is amazing the different treatment approaches each facility has.  I hope your treatments get easier for you.  The staff should really be a support to you.  Feel free to let them know what you need.  Each person is there to help you and sometimes we just have to push a little bit to remind them of that. Take care, Diane
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2008 05:13PM DianeE wrote: Hey Feb Rad Team I know I do not quite fit here as I started Rads in January and will finish next week, but I wanted to chime in on your coments.  I have felt very similar to Sue and Debby during my radiation treatments and wanted to give you suggestions on what has helped me.  I have had 26 treatments and have 7 more to go with boost starting Monday.  Each weekend, I try and plan something to mark the end of the week and acknowledge I have made it through another week of treatments.  I have blue eyes and fair skin and the skin reaction has not been that bad, it is the mental part I am fighting with.  Everyone tells me, you are such a trooper, you have come thru chemo, surgery and now radiation so well and I smile and think to myself, I am going to explode.  So another suggestion is to let the explosion happen.  I might stand in my shower and scream, cry and then be good for days.  I think I have been trying to protect my family by not showing how much this is really taxing on my mind, and not just my body.  I do not think I am to the point of needing meds, but keep in mind that there is nothing wrong with needing a little help in that area as well. My best to all of you as you begin treatment.  The radiaiton therapist will hopefully become your friends.  I am actually going to miss seeing some of them on a daily basis.  It does help to be chatty with them and take interest in their lives as it makes the time go faster and when they have that connection to you, well, it never hurts.  I treated mine to coffee and sweets this week and I know they really appreciated it.  Diane
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2008 08:38PM DianeE wrote: Hello everyone, I started rad tx on Jan 9 and will be done on Feb 22.  No problems with skin so far but I am diligent about using the lotion I was given.  Unlike other posters, I was told I could only use the lotion from them.  Anyone having chest wall and above the collar bone treatment?  I have started to notice some fatigue but compared to chemo, this is tolerable.  I went back to work part time as well so that might add to the fatigue.  Good luck to all of the Feb rads.  It is just one step in the journey to health and we can all  do it.
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2008 09:38PM DianeE wrote: Sue,  I have 13 of 33 rad treatments to go and have found Aquaphor to be my new best friend.  They want me to do it daily to prevent the skin irritation and tonight I am going to add Benadryl - oral to help with the itching that started yesterday.  Overall, this is really tolerable and I actually have been so chatty with the techs that I look forward to catching up with them.  The deoderant I was told to use is Crystal stick.  Since my double mastectomy, I no longer perspire.  No idea what is up with that.  I used to be able to sweat with the best of them.  Good luck as you start your treatment.  I hope it is as kind to you as it has been to me.  Now only if the hair on my head would grow at the rate of the hair on my legs, I would be a happy woman. Diane
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2008 04:42PM DianeE wrote: Ulla, Sorry you are going through this now but it does get better.  I finished rads Feb 22 and I will admit, it got worse before it got better.  The intensity of the redness and the pain peaked about 6 days after I finished, but by 2 weeks after I finished, the skin had totally healed and it was so much better.  My Rad Onc had me use a special wash followed by antibiotic cream as my skin broke down in large areas.  So, hang in there, rest and ask about pain meds if you haven't already.  I needed them to sleep during the peak time and it helped a lot.  It does get better, I promise. Diane
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 07:59AM DianeE wrote: Ulla, I am with you on the hair.   I had my last chemo on November 4 and my hair is maybe 1/2 to 3/4 inch long and fuzzy.  I still wear my wig as it is freezing in Wisconsin and it keeps me toasty.  Plus, I am not a big fan of the fuzz.  It will come soon enough, I know, but I am hoping by May to be sporting a "I did this on purpose" kind of hairdo.  I have had long hair my entire adult life and my wig is long so many are waiting for the unveiling of the head and I think it will be awhile yet!!!  I must say, I am getting use to the no fuss in the morning of popping it on and going.  Hope your hair starts to grow like weeds and that we are soon complaining of how frequently we have to get it cut!! Take care Diane
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2008 08:04PM DianeE wrote: I would encourage you not to delay in having the dermatology appointment.  It is wonderful if it is a skin only problem, and odds are it is, but skin thickening does need to be checked.  A biopsy may be in order and the derm can do that in their office the day of your visit.  I know where I live, derm appointments can be hard to get so if you need your pcp to make the appointment, make sure you engage their help. Good luck, Diane
Posts.Title: Very Worried LL8251 pinoideae

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 08:01PM DianeE wrote: Hi Roxy, Sending all the good luck and positive vibes your way.  I think the worrying about every ill feeling is going to be the hardest thing for me when treatment is done too.  Maybe your back pain is from lying on those oh so comfy radiation tables.  The other thing to consider is that I notice that I hold my body position more stiff and unrelaxed since I started radiation.  So, keep us posted and know that we are all in the waiting room and on the scanner table with you holding your hand and keeping you safe. Diane
Posts.Title: MRI SCARED roxy42 DianeE

Posts.Content: May 17, 2009 02:46PM DianeE wrote: Congratulations Linda and thanks for sharing your encouraging words.  I hope we do see leap and bound improvements in the near future with new meds targeted at our specific tumor types that make this beast a thing of the past.  Keep living it up! Posts.Title: I made it to 4 years!!! lkc candie1971

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 11:32PM DianeE wrote: Jeanne46- I work in an oncology center and have seen first hand some of my coworkers forget why they are there and who their "customers" are.  I would encourage you to ask for the clinic manager or a patient advocate.  Most clinics would appreciate the feedback and pass it on without using your name to their staff as a reminder to what the goals of the clinic should be.  I know my office does but needs reminders at times.  On another note, I have been reading some of the posts about the things that we do or do not like about our oncology centers.  I would love if more of those would be posted, or people could PM me as I am on a Quality Improvement panel to try and improve the process for the patients.  I think the office manager recognized what a resource I could be since I have been on both sides of the fence, as an employee and as a patient. Good luck to you.  Remember, you deserve the best in your care and if you have to teach some people what that includes, you are allowed!! Diane
Posts.Title: my onc's office needs a metster's club jeanne46 DianeE

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2009 07:34PM DianeE wrote: Amber, Your honest post was almost too much for me to read.  You verbalize what so many feel.  I am not where you are, so I can not begin to know what you are feeling.  I do know that only you knows when enough is enough, but girl, you are the opposite of a lousy Mom.  I go on your website daily (in fact my kids ask me about it now as I love the music and they recognize it) and your bright smile and kids warm my heart when I see their pictures.  Your courage will stay with them and teach them things that will not be realized now, but as they age, you will be their inspiration, the person that when they have to fill in the blank as a junior about "who they admire most", I have to believe its going to be you.  You have tought them about strength, faith, love, devotion, courage, hard work, dedication, determination, sacrifice, accepting kindness of others as an act of God, and the list goes on.  You are my inspirtation and what I strive for as we go through this journey.  So, please know, you are a wonderful Mom and an even better human being.  God Bless you!! Diane

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2008 04:38AM DianeE wrote: Janis Thrilled for your good news.  Yeah for you and your family.  This will allow you to enjoy the holidays with a little more reassurance that you are on the right track.  Thanks for posting your great news!! Diane
Posts.Title: I did get some good news.. Fitztwins celia088

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 10:47PM DianeE wrote: Kelly, I totally understand how you were feeling.  Here is what my onc said to brighten my day this week.  I had a PET and regular check up.  He was explaining his long term goals for me...5 years on tamoxifen, 5 years on an aromatase inhibitor and then at the 10 year mark there will probably be another drug to use and at 15, a cure.  That is exactly what I needed to hear so am passing it on.  Other docs have done the "you have a big fight ahead of you with inflammatory breast cancer, the prognosis is poor" and this man looks me in the eye and says "you are going to live a long time".  So, Kelly, you are going to live a long time and enjoy those monkeys and grand monkeys.  Happy Holidays!! Diane
Posts.Title: Gloom...but not the Doom KellyC JoyRebecca
